title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: rAccess package enables role-based access control teal modules, allowing : Restrict module access based user permissions Implement admin-functionality Dynamically filter modules runtime Provide graceful handling unauthorized access Users see interact modules authorized use.

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
code: library(uteals) library(teal) library(teal.modules.general) library(rAccess) library(shiny) library(bslib)

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: ’s minimal example get started:
code: # 1. Create modules mods <- modules(   tm_data_table("Data Table"),   tm_variable_browser("Variable Browser") )  # 2. Extract module structure extract_modules_to_yaml(mods, "panel_str.yml")  # 3. Filter modules by user permissions filtered_mods <- keep_by_label(mods, c("Data Table"))

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: Use extract_modules_to_yaml() function automatically generate module structure: creates:
code: # Define your teal modules mods <- modules(   tm_data_table("Data Table"),   tm_variable_browser("Variable Browser"),   tm_g_scatterplot("Scatterplot", x = ..., y = ...),   tm_outliers("Summary Statistics", outlier_var = ...) )  # Generate YAML structure extract_modules_to_yaml(mods, "panel_str.yml") # panel_str.yml panel_str: - access_panel: ADMIN - access_panel: Modules   access_units:   - unit: Data Table   - unit: Variable Browser   - unit: Scatterplot   - unit: Summary Statistics

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: Create main configuration file (rAccess_config.yml):
code: # rAccess_config.yml module: rAccess parameters:   app_name: TealAccessDemo   board_type: local   access_mode: default   unit_display: 'dropdown'   user_df: !expr tibble::tribble(     ~userid, ~username,     "user1", "Regular User",     "user2", "Limited User")   use_rconnect_users: FALSE   verbose: FALSE   secure_mode: FALSE  # Copy the panel_str section from generated file panel_str: - access_panel: ADMIN - access_panel: Modules   access_units:   - unit: Data Table   - unit: Variable Browser   - unit: Scatterplot   - unit: Summary Statistics

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
code: # Filter modules based on user access user_modules <- c("Data Table", "Variable Browser") filtered_modules <- keep_by_label(all_modules, user_modules)  # Remove specific modules restricted_modules <- remove_by_label(all_modules, c("Admin Panel"))

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
code: server <- function(input, output, session) {   # Get user identity   user_id <- ifelse(interactive(), Sys.getenv("USER"), session$user)    # Initialize rAccess   iam <- rAccess$new(user = user_id, config = "rAccess_config.yml")    # Get user permissions   user_access <- iam$get_user_accesslist()   allowed_modules <- unlist(user_access, use.names = FALSE)    # Filter modules   filtered_modules <- keep_by_label(all_modules, allowed_modules)    # Handle edge cases   if (is.null(filtered_modules)) {     filtered_modules <- create_no_access_module()   } }

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
code: # rAccess_config.yml module: rAccess parameters:   app_name: TealAccessDemo   board_type: local   access_mode: default   unit_display: 'dropdown'   user_df: !expr tibble::tribble(     ~userid, ~username,     "user1", "Regular User",     "user2", "Limited User")   use_rconnect_users: FALSE   verbose: FALSE   secure_mode: FALSE ### Data Setup # Prepare sample data data <- teal.data::teal_data(   IRIS = iris,   MTCARS = mtcars,   code = c("IRIS <- iris", "MTCARS <- mtcars") )  ### Module Definition # Define all available modules all_modules <- modules(   tm_data_table("Data Table"),   tm_variable_browser("Variable Browser"),   tm_g_scatterplot(     label = "Scatterplot",     x = data_extract_spec(       dataname = "IRIS",       select = select_spec(choices = variable_choices(iris))     ),     y = data_extract_spec(       dataname = "IRIS",       select = select_spec(choices = variable_choices(iris))     )   ),   tm_outliers(     label = "Summary Statistics",     outlier_var = data_extract_spec(       dataname = "MTCARS",       select = select_spec(choices = variable_choices(mtcars, c("mpg", "hp", "wt")))     )   ) )  ### UI Implementation ui <- bslib::page_navbar(   title = "Teal Access Demo",    # Main application tab   bslib::nav_panel(     "Analytics Modules",     uiOutput("teal_ui")   ),    # Admin panel (conditionally visible)   bslib::nav_panel(     "Access Control",     rAccess::module_iam_ui("access_control"),     tags$div(       class = "alert alert-info",       tags$h5("Administrator Panel"),       tags$p("Manage user access and permissions here.")     )   ) )  ### Server Implementation server <- function(input, output, session) {   # User authentication   user_id <- ifelse(interactive(), "user1", session$user)    # Initialize access control   iam <- rAccess$new(user = user_id, config = "rAccess_config.yml")    # Admin module server (conditional)   if (iam$no_admin() || iam$is_admin()) {     rAccess::module_iam_server("access_control", iam)   }    # Filter modules based on permissions   user_access_list <- iam$get_user_accesslist()   users_modules <- unlist(user_access_list, use.names = FALSE)   filtered_modules <- keep_by_label(all_modules, users_modules)    # Handle no access   if (is.null(filtered_modules)) {     filtered_modules <- modules(       module(         label = "No Access",         ui = function(id) tags$div(           class = "alert alert-warning",           h4("Access Restricted"),           p("You do not have permission to access any modules."),           p("Please contact your administrator.")         )       )     )   }    # Render teal UI   output$teal_ui <- renderUI({     tagList(       ui_teal("teal_app", filtered_modules),       ui_session_info("session_info")     )   })    # Teal server   srv_teal("teal_app", data = data, modules = filtered_modules)   srv_session_info("session_info") }  ### Application Launch # Create and run the application app <- shinyApp(ui, server)  # For development if (interactive()) {   runApp(app) }

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: app show different modules based user: - admin: Access admin panel - users: Access based rAccess permissions - Unauthorized users: “Access” message Note: define add least one admin, admin tab accessible everyone. least one admin defined, access control becomes enforced.

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: example, board_type: local configured rAccess_config.yml, access lists stored locally ./data/ directory within application. Alternative storage options include AWS S3 Posit Connect pins - refer rAccess documentation configuration details.

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
code: # Ensure the rAccess configuration (`rAccess_config.yml` in the example) is accessible by your app.  # Ensure module labels match exactly between configuration and code  # Enable verbose logging iam <- rAccess$new(user = user_id, config = "config.yml", verbose = TRUE)  # Check user access list print(iam$get_user_accesslist())  # Verify module labels print(sapply(all_modules$children, function(x) x$label))

title: Module Access Management with `rAccess`
text: uteals package provides essential utilities implementing access control teal applications: extract_modules_to_yaml(): Automates configuration generation keep_by_label(): Filters modules user permissions remove_by_label(): Excludes restricted modules integration enables secure, role-based access control maintaining flexibility power teal framework.

title: Change X-axis scaling decorator for teal.modules.clinical::tm_g_forest_rsp. — forestplot_x_decorator
code: library(teal.modules.clinical) #> Loading required package: teal #> Loading required package: shiny #> Loading required package: teal.data #> Loading required package: teal.code #> Loading required package: teal.slice #>  #> You are using teal version 1.1.0 #>  #> Attaching package: ‘teal’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:teal.slice’: #>  #>     as.teal_slices, teal_slices #> Loading required package: teal.transform #> Loading required package: tern #> Loading required package: rtables #> Loading required package: formatters #>  #> Attaching package: ‘formatters’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     %||% #> Loading required package: magrittr #>  #> Attaching package: ‘rtables’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:utils’: #>  #>     str data <- teal.data::teal_data() data <- within(data, {   ADSL <- teal.modules.clinical::tmc_ex_adsl   ADRS <- teal.modules.clinical::tmc_ex_adrs |>     dplyr::mutate(AVALC = tern::d_onco_rsp_label(AVALC) |>       formatters::with_label("Character Result/Finding")) |>     dplyr::filter(PARAMCD != "OVRINV" | AVISIT == "FOLLOW UP") }) teal.data::join_keys(data) <- teal.data::default_cdisc_join_keys[names(data)]  ADSL <- data[["ADSL"]] ADRS <- data[["ADRS"]]  arm_ref_comp <- list(   ARM = list(     ref = "B: Placebo",     comp = c("A: Drug X", "C: Combination")   ),   ARMCD = list(     ref = "ARM B",     comp = c("ARM A", "ARM C")   ) )  app <- teal::init(   data = data,   modules = teal::modules(     teal.modules.clinical::tm_g_forest_rsp(       label = "Forest Response",       dataname = "ADRS",       arm_var = choices_selected(         variable_choices(ADSL, c("ARM", "ARMCD")),         "ARMCD"       ),       arm_ref_comp = arm_ref_comp,       paramcd = choices_selected(         value_choices(ADRS, "PARAMCD", "PARAM"),         "INVET"       ),       subgroup_var = choices_selected(         variable_choices(ADSL, names(ADSL)),         c("BMRKR2", "SEX")       ),       strata_var = choices_selected(         variable_choices(ADSL, c("STRATA1", "STRATA2")),         "STRATA2"       ),       plot_height = c(600L, 200L, 2000L),       decorators = list(         plot = forestplot_x_decorator()       ),       default_responses = list(         BESRSPI = list(           rsp = c("Stable Disease (SD)", "Not Evaluable (NE)"),           levels = c(             "Complete Response (CR)", "Partial Response (PR)", "Stable Disease (SD)",             "Progressive Disease (PD)", "Not Evaluable (NE)"           )         ),         INVET = list(           rsp = c("Complete Response (CR)", "Partial Response (PR)"),           levels = c(             "Complete Response (CR)", "Not Evaluable (NE)", "Partial Response (PR)",             "Progressive Disease (PD)", "Stable Disease (SD)"           )         ),         OVRINV = list(           rsp = c("Progressive Disease (PD)", "Stable Disease (SD)"),           levels = c("Progressive Disease (PD)", "Stable Disease (SD)", "Not Evaluable (NE)")         )       )     )   ) ) #> Initializing tm_g_forest_rsp if (interactive()) {   shinyApp(app$ui, app$server) }

what: Create a forest plot from an rtable with x transform settings — g_forest_with_transform
title: Create a forest plot from an rtable with x transform settings — g_forest_with_transform
text: Given rtables::rtable() object least one column single value one column 2 values, converts table ggplot2::ggplot() object generates accompanying forest plot. table forest plot printed side--side.

title: Create a forest plot from an rtable with x transform settings — g_forest_with_transform
code: g_forest_with_transform(   tbl,   col_x = attr(tbl, "col_x"),   col_ci = attr(tbl, "col_ci"),   vline = 1,   forest_header = attr(tbl, "forest_header"),   xlim = c(0.1, 10),   transform_x = NA,   x_at = c(0.1, 1, 10),   width_columns = NULL,   lbl_col_padding = 0,   rel_width_forest = 0.25,   font_size = 12,   col_symbol_size = attr(tbl, "col_symbol_size"),   col = getOption("ggplot2.discrete.colour")[1],   ggtheme = NULL,   as_list = FALSE )

title: Create a forest plot from an rtable with x transform settings — g_forest_with_transform
text: tbl (VTableTree)rtables table least one column single value one column 2 values. col_x (integer(1) NULL) column index estimator. default tries get tbl attribute col_x, otherwise needs manually specified. NULL, points excluded forest plot. col_ci (integer(1) NULL) column index confidence intervals. default tries get tbl attribute col_ci, otherwise needs manually specified. NULL, lines excluded forest plot. vline (numeric) position vertical reference line plot. like 0 1 forest plot. forest_header (character(2)) text displayed left right vline, respectively. vline = NULL forest_header printed. default tries get tbl attribute forest_header. NULL, defaults extracted table possible, set "Comparison\nBetter" "Treatment\nBetter" . xlim (numeric) range x-axis limits. Example: c(0.1, 10) transform_x (character) function x-values transformation x_at (numeric) specifies tick marks axis. value union(xlim, vline) Example: c(0.1,1,10). width_columns (numeric) vector column widths. element's position colwidths corresponds column tbl position. NULL, column widths calculated according maximum number characters per column. lbl_col_padding (numeric) padding label columns value. Default 0. rel_width_forest (proportion) proportion total width allocate forest plot. Relative width table 1 - rel_width_forest. as_list = TRUE, parameter ignored. font_size (numeric(1)) font size. col_symbol_size (numeric NULL) column index tbl containing data used determine relative size estimator plot symbol. Typically, symbol size proportional sample size used calculate estimator. NULL, symbol size used subgroups. default tries get tbl attribute col_symbol_size, otherwise needs manually specified. col (character) color(s). ggtheme (theme) graphical theme provided ggplot2 control styling plot. as_list (flag) whether two ggplot objects returned list. TRUE, named list two elements, table plot, returned. FALSE (default) table forest plot printed side--side via cowplot::plot_grid().

title: Create a forest plot from an rtable with x transform settings — g_forest_with_transform
text: ggplot forest plot table.

title: ggplot decorator — ggplot_decorator
text: Decorator function update various settings ggplot plot objects

title: ggplot decorator — ggplot_decorator
code: ggplot_decorator(   output_name,   label_text = "decorator",   render_ui = c(),   plot_options = list(title = "", footnote = "", y_breaks = "", y_limits_max = "",     y_limits_min = "", x_breaks = "", x_labels_discrete = "", x_labels_cont = "",     y_labels_discrete = "", y_labels_cont = "", font_size_geom_text = "",     font_size_plot_title = "", font_size_axis_title = "", font_size_axis_text = "") )

title: ggplot decorator — ggplot_decorator
text: output_name name output plot object. label_text customized label text decorator render_ui vector ggplot_options following list: "title" - Title plot, "footnote" - Footnote plot, "y_breaks" - Value breaks(numeric) y-axis. Note: y_limits_max y_limits_min also provided, "y_limits_max" - Value y-axis maximum limit(numeric). Note: y_limits_max y_breaks also provided, "y_limits_min" - Value y-axis minimum limit(numeric). Note: y_breaks y_limits_min also provided, "x_breaks"- Value breaks continuous x-axis(numeric). Note: comma separated, "x_labels_discrete" - Values labels discrete x-axis. Note: comma separated, "x_labels_cont" - Values labels continuous x-axis. Note: comma separated, "y_labels_discrete" - Values labels discrete y-axis. Note: comma separated, "y_labels_cont" - Values labels continuous y-axis. Note: comma separated, "font_size_geom_text" - Font size geom_text. Note: numeric value provided, "font_size_plot_title"- Font size plot title text. Note: numeric value provided, "font_size_axis_title"- Font size axis title text. Note: numeric value provided, "font_size_axis_text"- Font size axis labels text. Note: numeric value provided plot_options named list list values ggplot options. app developer can specify required list options calling decorator.

title: ggplot decorator — ggplot_decorator
text: teal::teal_transform_module Returns modified plot object transformation applied.

title: ggplot decorator — ggplot_decorator
text: module creates UI text controls specifying list ggplot options given plot_options parameter value. entered ggplot options applied ggplot plot object.

title: ggplot decorator — ggplot_decorator
code: app <- teal::init(   data = teal.data::teal_data(IRIS = iris, code = "IRIS <- iris"),   modules = teal::modules(     teal.modules.general::tm_g_scatterplot(       x = teal.transform::data_extract_spec(         dataname = "IRIS",         select = teal.transform::select_spec(choices = teal.transform::variable_choices(iris))       ),       y = teal.transform::data_extract_spec(         dataname = "IRIS",         select = teal.transform::select_spec(choices = teal.transform::variable_choices(iris))       ),       decorators = list(         plot = ggplot_decorator(           output_name = "plot", render_ui = c("title", "footnote", "font_size_axis_title")         )       )     )   ) ) #> Initializing tm_g_scatterplot if (interactive()) {   shinyApp(app$ui, app$server) }

what: Apply Logical AND/OR filter transformations — or_filtering_transformator
title: Apply Logical AND/OR filter transformations — or_filtering_transformator
text: transformator provides users flexible, dynamic filtering capabilities datasets. instance transformator operates single dataset. Users can define multiple filter blocks, : Conditions within block combined logical . Multiple blocks combined logical . allows creating complex filter expressions like: (Condition1 Condition2) (Condition3 Condition4) apply filtering across multiple datasets, users can instantiate multiple instances module, configured different dataset. module call independent manages filters specific dataset. Supported Data Types & Expressions: Supports filtering character, factor, numeric columns. Conditions can use operators: ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=. Conditions specified simple expressions, e.g., columnA == 'value' columnB != 5 columnC >= 10 block's conditions combined . Multiple blocks combined . Features: Add Multiple Blocks: Dynamically add new blocks alternative conditions. Add Conditions: Within block, add multiple conditions, duplicate prevention. Preview Filter Expression: Generate display current combined filter expression. Remove Conditions: Remove individual conditions within block. Expression Generation: resulting expression can directly used dplyr::filter() similar functions. Usage Pattern: Call module multiple times different dataset names filter multiple datasets independently. call manages filter state expression. Users can build complex filters per dataset apply combine needed.

title: Apply Logical AND/OR filter transformations — or_filtering_transformator
code: or_filtering_transformator(dataname)

title: Apply Logical AND/OR filter transformations — or_filtering_transformator
text: dataname (character(1)) Name dataset filter. Pass single dataset name string.

text: filtered teal modules object matching modules removed, NULL modules removed.

title: Remove Teal Modules by Label — remove_by_label
code: mods <- teal::modules(   teal::example_module("mod1"),   teal::example_module("mod2") ) # Remove a single module filtered_mods <- remove_by_label(mods, "Deaths")  # Remove multiple modules filtered_mods <- remove_by_label(mods, c("Deaths", "Lab Summary Table"))

title: Title and Footer Decorator — title_footer_decorator
text: function create UI component selecting title footer tables plots. reads title information specified Excel file allows users choose title provided options. also provides user flexibility customize title footer according specific needs.

title: Title and Footer Decorator — title_footer_decorator
code: title_footer_decorator(output_name, titles_file)

title: Title and Footer Decorator — title_footer_decorator
text: output_name (character(1)) name output object (e.g., plot table). titles_file (character(1)) path Excel file containing title footer information. function expects titles first sheet named "Sheet1".

title: Title and Footer Decorator — title_footer_decorator
text: teal::teal_transform_module()

title: Title and Footer Decorator — title_footer_decorator
text: module creates UI dropdown selecting title. title selected, updates output either adding titles table modifying plot's title caption accordingly. Additionally, includes checkbox user can check enable customization, allowing enter values title footer designated input fields.
